commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. They might have their noses turned up  (9)
2. Places where it's OK to push someone at school  (5)(4)
3. Heat setting, perhaps  (4)
4. Kick-starter program?  (6)(7)
5. Device for cutting bangs?  (8)


AIRPLANES
SWING SETS
MEET
KARATE LESSONS
SILENCER
This puzzle brought to you by Linda Ronstadt: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=6ookPAQ2yJI
Fun Monday! Thanks, Lynn!
Fun 10m47s puzzle.
I think this is my first true under 10 minutes solve. I enjoyed it as well.
I like it when a Monday puzzle has a theme!
This was pretty easy, mostly due to the remarkable amount of repeated words (NAY, ASP, ONO, ELM) and even clues  (1D, 59D, 21D, etc).
La Paz is not the capital of Bolivia!!

Very solid Monday theme, though "nougat" would have been nice somewhere in the grid!

BATIK/BLINI might be a bit rough for a Monday. And perhaps the clue for BOGO could have indicated that the answer is an initialism. (Let me guess---BOGO has already earned its word-hood.) If it weren't Monday, we could have had "___-Indian (chess defense)".

Nice puzzle, all in all.

Our constructor writes:
     Surprisingly few clues were changed from the ones I submitted.

Ms. Lempel,
By this, your 103rd NYT XWP, I would expect you to know what the editors look for in clues. Thanks for the delightful Monday puzzle!
Some YOYOs claim that a NUDISTCAMP is a NEUTRALZONE.  SOWHATELSEISNEW?

Nu, I must still have yesterday’s James Bond lingering in my head.
Right away, at 1A, my brain said “Berg.  Ice Berg.”

1a was a gimme and allowed me to settle into the ease of the puzzle. Also enjoyed the globe spanning food entrees. From blini to noodle soup and sea salt to pea. Thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle and loved that I came in almost 3 minutes under my average

Who knew what a cute puzzle Lynn would create? I imagine we all did. Thank you, Lynn. 

Happy Labor Day, Crosslandia ☺️

I liked the puzzle, but quite possibly the hardest Monday puzzle I've ever seen.

Just to have BATIK, BLINI, and LAPAZ all intersecting each other.  And BOERS and SATEEN.  Most Mondays I just bulldoze through, today I had like three squares at the end I had to cycle all grammatically reasonable letters.

Nice and smooth Monday. After the first two and the revealer I tried to guess the next two themed entries; I was close with NOODLEDISH but was off with NOUVEAU RICHE which would have been a letter too long anyway. Another cheeky answer to SOWHATELSEISNEW is “It’s a Yiddish word that can be used in all sorts of contexts” as explained by Mayim Bialik in this short video: https://www.tiktok.com/@mayimbialik/video/7242378660068609323?lang=en
It's a pleasure to solve a construction from Lynn Lempel, and not a New Sensation. https://youtu.be/KygvdzH0gj4?si=26KTr0z7gV0H76w5 Emus, they're Aussies, let them through.

The puzzle was ACES! NEUTRALZONE made me think of Star Trek, which you've probably figured out recently I'm a big fan of! 😂 Granted, there are a other great songs about kisses, but I really love this one and I think of it I think every time it comes up in the crossword, which is fairly often. I don't think I've shared this out here before though. It's an earworm that I never mind!! https://youtu.be/fHjZQb-kGek?si=B6Fz4l2qfnjm_ZHb
“Wallops” is a delightful word and a lovely way to add some sparkle to a common clue/answer combination for ACES.
Very nice puzzle but a bit of a frustrating theme for someone who is used to Australian pronunciation 😅

I used to prefer amphibians, but now I like wildebeests. Out with the toad, in with the gnu!

(Stop me if you've herd this one.)
I'd prefer to attribute human hubris as Titanic's undoing, even though iceberg was the direct cause of its destruction.
BLINI crossing BATIK is a little natick-y for a Monday

A Pall was cast on the Nudist Camp. Someone had crossed the Neutralized Zone. People shielding their eyes. Offense being taken. There he was, a fully clothed man wandering around looking  like it was the most natural thing in the world.

The best kind of Monday puzzle is one that doesn’t feel like a Monday puzzle. 

This one wasn’t too difficult, but the clues definitely required some thought. It was a skillful balance, and I appreciate the extra effort.

A nice breezy puzz, not too laborious for this Labor Day.
A day I hope you all celebrate safely and enjoyably.
And if you can make the scene at a local protest demonstration, bless you!

Monday puzzles walk a fine line:  too hard, some say; too easy, others claim, plus they are supposed to be entertaining, with supporting crosses to clear up any possible unknowns.  This one hits all the marks.

Congratulations, Lyyn Lempel, you created a puzzle that we can all enjoy.  Thank you for this gem.

Interesting! The puzzle didn't *feel* easy yet I solved it in near record time. It would have been harder had I not remembered BATIK from a previous NYT grid 🙂

One entry today reminded me of when I used to travel around Europe with my parents in the 1990s. Since Polish prosperity at the time did not match Western European levels, we had to stay at campsites - it was all we could afford. Germans love camping and back then they issued a guide to all European campsites. It described the facilities, and the level of comfort. There were also other designations, which we did not understand. Travelling in Germany, we looked in the guide and saw a very highly rated yet affordable campsite on our route. It was designated as FKK, which was explained in the legend only in German: Freikörperkultur. We did not understand what that might be.

So, we arrived at the campsite, nestled in the hills of the German countryside, in a truly idyllic spot. It was at the end of a long drive, and surrounded by a 3 m hedge. At first my attention was focused on a very nice Jaguar parked in the entrance area. Then I heard a sound of surprise from my mother. I looked around and saw loads of naked people walking around. It was quite surreal.

We learned FKK is the German NUDIST movement, and they have their own campsites.
It's considered rude to wear any clothes there. My mother wanted to stay the night in the buff (she was quite free spirited), but friends we traveled with wouldn't hear of it 🤣.

A little too easy?  I love an easy puzzle but this one blew my personal best time by 90 seconds... That's NUTS.  Across, down, DONE.   I thought something was wrong when I didn't start the second pass.  Never happened before.   

Anyway, thanks for the ear worm .. Ebony and Ivory is a good one to have on a Monday ;)

They call Lynn Lempel the queen of the Mondays for some very good reasons. This is her 74th Monday, and the quality, as always, is very high.

We haven't seen her work for a while, it's been almost two years since her last Monday, and about a year and a half since her last Times puzzle (a Tuesday), so it's very nice to see one from her again.

Excellent as usual, and thanks!
They had a new gnu at the zoo https://www.middlemiss.org/lit/authors/denniscj/newspapers/herald/1935/works/elusivenewzoognu.html Something of an lesser known Australian classic

That photo for today's column was a very nasty dig at Zohran Mamdani. I don't want to get poltiical here, but if I wanted a muscle man, I would have tried to get Pete Buttigieg, Arnold Schwartzenegger, or The Incredible Hulk here. I am ONLY interested in Zohran's brains and energy. You don't have to agree with me, but that picture was not appreciated.

Excellent! 

I confidently put 'tat' for tourist souvenir! The only clue I had to think about, as I would always say 'T-shirt' and not TEE.

One of my fastest and smoothest since I started, with unknowns (insurers and the like) solved by crossers. 

Out of curiosity, what items are covered by the NUISANCE TAX, or is it a joke?
I was prepared to be all ‘yes, but we pronounce it neu, not noo’ . But Ms Lempel gave us both. Clever. Very clever. Brava.
A paper solver I've taken to using a clipboard while reclining.  Got to the end of this gem and wondered, "Who did this?".  Raised the clip.   Ah.  Of course.  Perfection.
I love a Lynn Lempel puzzle!

It was the best of puzzles, it was the worst of puzzles, it was the puzzle of wisdom, it was the puzzle of foolishness, it was the puzzle of belief, it was the puzzle of incredulity, it was the puzzle of Light, it was the puzzle of Darkness, it was the puzzle of hope, it was the puzzle of despair.

Bravo. Congratulations. Now I'll walk out in a huff.

This was such a great Monday. Appropriately quick to solve but clever and not boring. Didn’t realized the creator was a beloved puzzle maker till I checked the comments but it makes perfect sense! Now I am a fan too!
Nyooodle soup?? Or is everything else just “noo”? Nooodist camp? Nooootral zone? Nooosance tax? Surely not?
A good example of why Lynn is considered the queen of Mondays.  A nice start to the week,  thanks, Lynn.

In my hippie days, there was a place in upstate NY, probably the Catskills region, called Su Casa. I can't even find it in an extensive search now, but it was the place to go. So I went for the weekend, along with two girlfriends. We checked in and headed for the pool, my new camera hanging from a strap around my neck. I was stopped at the gate and told I couldn't come in with the camera. With all I had read about the place in the Village Voice, I somehow missed the part about it being a nudist resort! Today's 17A brought back that long-ago memory. 

Thanks, Lynn, for a terrific and entertaining puzzle. Queen of Mondays, indeed!

@Times Rita

Wish there were an edit button. It was nudist at the pool only.

Two thumbs up. Always enjoy a Lynn Lempel puzzle and this one was a lot of fun. Pretty smooth solve and the reveal was almost the last thing I worked out. Nice 'aha' moment when I looked at the other theme answers and finally caught on. And a fun puzzle find today. A Wednesday from February 5, 2014 by Tracy Gray. Four theme answers in that one and I'll put the notable string in each of them in parentheses. HELLORHIG(HWATE)R (THEWA)LTONS GR(EATWH)ITE SO(WHATE)LSEISNEW And then the reveal: "Breakfast cereal ... or a hint to what's found in the answers to the four starred clues?" SHREDDEDWHEAT Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/5/2014&g=59&d=A ....

ONO, bad news.
But no "gnus" is good news.

(You *knew* someone would bring up the crosswordese.)

Lynn’s puzzles are liltingly smooth, with an elegant feel, and filled with lovely touches in answer and clue.  They’ve always been, and she’s been making NYT puzzles for 46 years.  Mondays are her specialty, making up almost three-quarters of her 103 puzzles.

Standouts today:
•	Alliteration in clues – [Ticker in a taxi], [Flexible Flyer, for one], [“Bald” birds].
•	Echoes in SATEEN / TEEN, and ACCRUE, RUES.
•	Bouncy trochaic trio of BOGO, YOYOS, and ONO.  And that “double-O” vibe serendipitously recalls yesterday’s JAMES BOND puzzle.

The themes that come out of LL’s bean are catchy and fun.  What a marvelous revealer today.

I see your name atop a puzzle, Lynn, and I know I’m going to leave it feeling warm, entertained, and richer for having experienced a brush with beauty.  As I was today.  Thank you!

The sarcastic answer to 35A: "New York, New Jersey..."

Jumped on POGO for 68A. only to rewind my string of zipping through this great puzzle.
Thought I was 'walking the dog' with this one! 
I was feeling 'around the world' getting so close to a PB!

This might be my favorite Monday puzzle in a long time. The revealer is so perfect. 

I’ve a soft spot for this kind of theme. I still fondly remember Andrea Carla Michael’s “way” homophones, with Anchors Aweigh and Ai Weiwei, and that’s been a couple of years at least.

I had one minor snag that slowed me down — NOODLE bOwl. 

Favorite clue: The one for NUDIST CAMP. 

Thanks for the fun, Ms Lempel!

Ooohh - my usual late puzzle find. A quite unusual one - a Sunday from November 1, 1970 by A.J. Santora with the title: "Squarely figured." That one had numerals as rebuses in several squares Some examples: (10)DOWNINGSTREET (40)WINKS ROUTE(66) (80)DAYS And the one that led me there: (76)TROMBONES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/1/1970&g=76&d=D ....
I was off by a letter.  LAMAZ didn't feel right but what do I know about Bolivia?  I do find that MALLS have a dreary atmosphere.

I think good Monday puzzles are very hard to write.  They need to be accessible to those who are just starting out, but interesting to those who have been solving for a while.
This one hits the sweet spot.  I found it easy, breezy, but the clues and the solutions were fresh and held my interest.  And the theme was original and amusing, but not too tricky for the newbie.
Hmm, "newbie"?  Could that have found its way into today's puzzle?

Thanks, Lynn Lempel, for a lovely way to start the week.

Is everyone up early on this holiday Monday?  100 Comments already!  
What is a NUISANCE TAX?  A "fine" I could understand, but a TAX?  
Other than that, of course this was a nice puzzle with a number of clues and entries that I never read due to their having been bypassed/filled already...

19A reminded me of a funny bit from a small-town newspaper:
An article about a recent funeral included a report, as follows:
"Mr. Eaton suffered a broken leg, having fallen into the open grave at the cemetary.  The incident cast a PALL of gloom over the entire proceedings."
BOGO?
Fun and well done! This puzzle is an excellent source of commonly used answers and should be required "solving"  for new puzzle solvers.

Me: Hey, ALEXA, you're in today's Crossword Puzzle!
Alexa: Bingo! What number am I? 
Me: 42 Across
Alexa: 42 Across! I guess I'm not just helping you with the puzzles in your life, I'm helping you with your crossword puzzles too!

When you play a game in the archives, why are they sometimes blue and sometimes gold when you complete them? I know blue is if you get help. I just finished an old Tuesday puzzle and did not get hints but it appeared blue - is it because I started it one day and finished it another day? (This is not a big problem! I am just curious what the rules are.)

As for 43A "Global extremity" for POLE: Certainly, the poles have the extreme latitudes on Earth, 90º N and S. 

But geometrically, the globe is flattened at the poles, so in this sense they are not extremities but just the opposite.

Fun puzzle and a great revealer! But imo the undoer of "Titanic" was the door thing. Selfish Rose.

So is dodgeball a common corporate team-building activity? (see photo)
Who says “nyoodle”?!
Smooth and seamless solving got me a new PB of 3:12!  Woo hoo!

pedantic editor to foreign correspondent:
   Are there any news?
foreign correspondent to pedantic editor:
   Not a new.

Allegedly true story. Can't remember the source (if I ever knew).

Oh - one more late puzzle find. NEVER seen another one like this. Really clever. Anyway - a Sunday from June 22, 1997 by Matt Gaffney with the title: "Full-Length Features." All the theme answers were just clued as a film from a particular year. e.g. - the clue for the first one was: 1944 film. And that answer: MEETMEINSTPERIODLOUIS And the other theme answers: HELPEXCLAMATIONPOINT NOBODYAPOSTROPHESFOOL QUOVADISQUESTIONMARK SORRYCOMMAWRONGNUMBER Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/22/1997&g=112&d=A ....
Here's the link to the BOGO article https://seaswell.wordpress.com/2007/12/04/payless-shoes-and-the-bogo-ad-campaign/
Entre nous, not much to say about a Monday puzzle.

Really?!?!

NYT crossword is going to clue BOERS as “Descendants of Dutch settlers of Southern Africa”?!?!

Way to “white” wash it. 

You could easily have clued it as “Dutch farmers” since “Boer” means farmer in Dutch or go further by being honest with something like “The Dutch colonists whose presence led eventually to the Apartheid state of South Africa”.
Wordle in two today.

Oh! And one more find - this time a pair of puzzles. Can't help but wonder if this was just an odd coincidence. Anyway - A Saturday from August 8, 1992 by Eileen Lexau. and.. A Thursday from April 30, 1998 by Kelly Clark. In both of those puzzles, 3 down was: TUBPUSIXNORBEHT And both of the clues referenced it being joined with another 12 down. One clue/answer example: With 12 Down, lines from "New York, New York" : TUBPUSIXNORBEHT and the clue in the other one: With 11-Down, "On the Town" lyric, appropriately : TUBPUSIXNORBEHT And in both them the referenced down answer was: THEBATTERYSDOWN In the 1992 puzzle the middle down clue and answer was: "He wrote the music for "New York, New York" BERNSTEIN But in the 1998 puzzle there were two other theme answers. One was 9-down: "O'Neal/Streisand comedy, appropriately" CODPUSTAHW and... 29 down: "Comment from Popeye, appropriately" BLOWMEDOWN Here are the links to Xword Info for those puzzles: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=8/8/1992&g=12&d=D https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/30/1998&g=3&d=D I'm done....
I’ve been missing our old friend OBOE, hope it turns up soon 🧐

This was a good puzzle to start off a new month and essentially a new week! Here are my suggestions for the hints to a couple answers: 32 Across should have been, “the current administration and its leader have serious fragile ones” and 44 Down should have been, “what the ICE agents need to do”. 
I enjoyed the theme very much so since I’m pretty much all about being nude lol! Less is best!!
Anyways, I hope all my fellow NYTers are having a Marvellous Monday and Namaste!

Hi there,
I believe I’ve found a mistake in today’s crossword puzzle. The Capital of Bolivia is SUCRE, not LAPAZ.
La Paz is Bolivia’s seat of government.

Oh... one more puzzle (sorry). A Sunday from July 10, 2005 by Con Pederson with the title: "New ar-rangements" A couple of clue/answer examples: Supper at home before unpacking from a move? : DININGALACRATE Mild swearing competition? : AGAMEOFDRATS And some other theme answers: FRAMERINTHEDELL HAVEANERAFORMUSIC GOTOWRAPSPEED WELLREGRADED ILLEGALRAMSDEAL ROLLINGOUTTHETRAP HAVEANERAFORMUSIC Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/10/2005&g=28&d=A ....

Home from my daily labors, and able to dip into Wordplay. Here is to day's earworm, one of the great rail-road songs, right up there with "the City of New Orleans," "Pacific 231," and Steve Reich's *Different Trains": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bBNddLOTMkY&list=RDbBNddLOTMkY&start_radio=1 (Introduced to me by a fellow Wordplayer; and I will continue to post this each time it comes up as an entry, which is pretty often.) Here is a 1:12 clip from one of my two all-time favorite movies (Sorry for the English dubbing): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fwnmr18o214. (And here's what a pancake can inspire in one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5jOn7biSAZo) Other folk have linked lots of fun songs about gnus and kisses; here's one of my favorites: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5uZQFOfMSfY&list=RD5uZQFOfMSfY&start_radio=1
Crossword in 5:48, missed “best” by :25.  I just ❤️ Mondays!  Noo question about it!
My favorite clue is 35 Across, "So what else is new?" Love the pun on all the "new" homophones.

what I love about crosswords, even one as charmingly easy as today's, is that i always learn something new. I've never really thought about elm leaves, nut now know they are oval shaped. Grazie, Lynn!

My last square, I was stuck on _ATIK and _LINI

I was just lucky the answer wasn't ZATIK and ZLINI

insensitive cluing to a fault Boers and Spotify both instantly called out of ALL the clues and answers both involve hurting others to the EXTREME

always enjoyed Lynn this is a bridge too far better luck next time
Is it just me or does the word MUESLI look and sound disgusting?

great puzzle just wish things that caused such epic harm to others like Spotify and Boers and Aetna honestly - they truly do each of those clues have caused endless suffering to others even though its not all bad could have been a better word say Nelson Mandela Bandcamp (artists get the $ and folks can't steal our music for free) and we all know what its like to have Aetna or an insurer turn down a legitimate doctor approved claim.  thanks Lynn cute theme!

I can't resist reposting the "Ode to Aplomb" composed by @Francis and me on Sunday:
Francis:
I think that I shall never see
A word more lovely than APLOMB.
Me:
ELAN is good.
And GRACE is surer. 
But better still Is 
SPREZZATURA.

[Yes that is the correct spelling]
Instead of “settlers,” why don’t we start using “colonizers?”

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[R as in Rolls-Royce?]  (7)
[Guide for writing a perfect letter]  (7)


REVERSE
STENCIL
@Lewis I’m shurprised that SHINEDSHIELDDELIVERED didn’t make the lisht

Petrol,
I may be mistaken, but I think Lewis's "week"  runs Sunday through Saturday, so if 007 shows up it will be in next week's report.

@Petrol -- Alas, the magnificent SHINEDSHIELDDELIVERED is not a clue.
@Barry -- My week is M-Su.

@HeathieJ -- I went back and forth on this one.  I loved the clue, but I hate all things gun.  Now I'm feeling more bad than good about having it on the list, and that will inform my future lists. I'm sorry for having reminded you about it, and thank you for expressing your feelings on this!

HeathieJ,
As I wrote, "I may be mistaken..."!

Lewis,
My sense -- and again, I may be mistaken -- is that your favorite clues are rarely themer clues (which may fall into another category).
@Barry Ancona -- Good observation!  I rarely have included themer clues, though I have from time to time when they were particularly good.

@Lewis

Thanks for your kind and thoughtful response, Lewis!  And I totally know what you mean... The clue is very cute and clever. I think that's what actually made it more jarring for me. I just can't any longer seem to separate myself from how  devastating our nation is in regards to guns and what seems a complete disregard for life.

@Barry Ancona

Yeah, I caught that in your first line... Sorry if I accidentally implied (when I replied) that you were making an absolute assertion or anything. Not my intent!  ☺️

@Steve L
A beautiful version and from an album filled with lovely covers. What a shame that she no longer sings.

@SBK
Agree.  Parkinson's.  Such a devastating disease.

@Steve L

Thanks, Steve. Rex Parker also posted this on his blog, which I always go to first. But it's so beautiful that I'm going to listen to it again. Breaks my heart that she can't sing anymore.

@Kasa Cotugno

I believe that she was originally misdiagnosed with Parkinson's, and that she instead has supranuclear palsy.

@Steve L

Our “Standards” playlist has all three of her albums with those classics. Her version of My Funny Valentine is by far my favorite.

@Eric Hougland

If I had to pick a favorite among the songs on those three albums, it might be “Someone to Watch Over Me” or “When You Wish Upon a Star.”
@Elizabeth Connors what do you mean by "true"?

@Elizabeth Connors


Did you get it in one pass through. Meaning once through the across and once through the downs?
A rarity for me but I did today. Giggle worthy.

The above comment was supposed to go here🤓
Good news: virtually all Monday puzzles have themes.

@Rich

Sucre is the constitutional capital of Bolivia, but two-thirds of the government is in La Paz (executive and legislative). Only the judiciary is in Sucre. This, La Paz is widely considered a second capital. In fact, it is often touted as the highest-altitude capital in the world.

@Ricb
Oh come on!  I remember learning in 9th grade that Bolivia was this odd country with two capitals. (Don't they make kids memorize capitals any more?)
@Alex I don't agree that the clue should say "administrative capital". It would make you think less and not try to think outside the box.

@tony But then you could have [Capital of the USA] and it could be pretty much any city since they're all described as "the *something* capital of the USA"... La Paz is the same essentially, only unofficially described as a certain kind of capital. In official terms, the capital of The USA is Washington DC and the capital of Bolivia is Sucre, nothing else.
"Boliviano" would be the "outside the box" answer to [Capital of Bolivia].

@Barry Ancona

I worked for a newspaper for years and never, ever figured out what the editors look for, other than making my life as miserable as possible.

@Barry,

Barry, I was discussing your comment with my neighbor, Mr. Wilson, and he said he was surprised that I am surprised that you were surprised that Ms. Lempel was surprised that few clues were changed from the ones Ms. Lempel submitted.
@Megan -- ... and don't forget the backward STEW.
@Chris yep, thanks for these. I was just wondering where to go with these crosses.
@Chris - same, got stuck on both crosses myself. Hard for a Monday!
@Andrzej  My experience with this puzzle was very much like yours. And, like you, I often find myself floundering while others complain the puzzle is too easy.
@Chris It always amazes me how individual our reactions are.  My thought was, "Easiest crossword I've ever done."  One man's meat....

@MExpat

I too thought it was quite easy — so much so that I thought I was headed for a new personal best. In the end, I wasn’t at close to my PB, but it was fun anyway.

@HeathieJ

I learned NEUTRAL ZONE from Star Trek before I knew of any on Earth 🤣

@Andrz
Earth is so overrated!!  😂

@HeathieJ

thanks for Louis!

@Mike

I do admire the eland of your puns!

@Mike
Savvanahr eight species left to go. Good to see that you're not lion around. When you come up with your next one, we'll snag a giraffe of wine and have a party. (Be sure to be wearing your cheetahs when you decide.)
@Mike DOGgone it, but your puns were RATTLERS. I CANARY BEAR to try to beat them. TOUCAN EMU I guess.

@Mike
So what else is newt?

@Mike

A variation of your idea:  I used to prefer fungi, but now I like wildebeests.  Out with the mold, in the with the gnu.  Maybe it will grow on you (figuratively, not literally).

Heidi,

When I saw the 1A clue and only four letters for the answer, I briefly wondered if we would see a Monday rebus for "hubris." And in a Labor Day puzzle I wanted 29D to be a rebus for "union."
N.B. With the abbr. signal in 29D, "AFLCIO."

@Cody

Hey, you're in Minneapolis....   Cross the river and go visit Moscow on the Hill!! 

The BLINIs and everything else is divine.

If you like martinis, you should probably take an Uber cuz they're amazing!

☺️🪆
@HeathieJ Made me want some blintzes with sour cream. Yummy. My dad made the best ones.

@HeathieJ

When I came to the Twin Cities in the early aughts (love you that sounds), I was so excited to explore some of those places like Moscow on the Hill, in the Cathedral area.

Hasn't happened at all, for the most part.  I think when we first got to town that meals at places like that had to be extremely infrequent. 

Now that things have eased up a bit (though it still feels like an extravagance) but now most of the initial excitement is gone.

For example, the first time I was downtown Minneapolis I saw the sign for Murray's Steak House.  I swore, swore to myself I'd treat myself there soon, so enchanted was I by the big city mid-western 50s style steak house.  

Never made it in over 20 years.
@Cody Respectfully disagree: Both are really common words, adopted by American English. Especially BATIK.
@Cody Agreed, it made the NE corner pretty impenetrable unfortunately.

@Francis

Yeah, it's easy to be excited at the newness. I try to have us pretend to be tourists in our own area sometimes because there are so many great things here. 

After living here for about 15 years, I even went and tossed my beret with good ole Mar!! (As in the Mary Tyler Moore show statue!) ☺️

I've only been to Murray's once (not a huge steak person) but Moscow on the Hill is a long time favorite. I first tried it before I went to Siberia to see what the food might be like. When I came back, I loved it even more. And I adore the whole Cathedral Hill area!!

@CLN I’m a 42-yr-old American having lived in TX, the Midwest and NYC for long stretches of time and don’t recall having ever heard or seen “BATIK.” I love learning new things via the Crossword and don’t mind a little crunch in my Mondays, but calling it “really common” is a bit of stretch.

@Andrzej. To add to this. In this part of Australia, Labour Day is the first Monday in October, used to be called “Eight hours day from the slogan “Eight hours work, eight hours rest, eight hours sleep “.

@Andrzej

We had a similar experience about 30 years ago.  We had a lot of friends together in a church campground in the hills between Silicon Valley and the Pacific ocean.  After breakfast on Saturday we all drove down to the nearest beach and parked.  While the parents worked on unloading the cars of their beach gear the teenagers dashed down the hill to the water.  

They shortly came back stating that we had better go to a different beach.  This was Davenport -- one of the few "swimsuits optional" beaches in California.  Oops.  Parents agreed.

We all piled back in the cars and drove a little south to the State Beach at Santa Cruz and had a lovely day.

@Jane Wheelaghan

A nuisance tax or junk fee  is added to the price of a product or service when a business needs to recoup a new cost but doesn't want the customer to blame the business.
For instance, if fuel prices spike, a shipping or delivery business might add a fuel sucharge to the invoice. Thus putting the blame on the economy or the oil cartels or politicians.
A hotel might add a charge if the local town just added or increased a bed tax.

@Eric Hougland

Fun Fact: I worked with an older (to me, I was 24) lady back in the late 70s who I thought was a little odd. She was gray haired, smelled of talcum powder, had an eye you avoided because it avoided you, and always said things like "I've been rich and I've been poor, and believe me, rich is better!" She lived in one of the famous hotels downtown, and worked as an editor in the desk next to mine on a top trade magazine in NYC. She, like most office mates, talked about what went on in her daily life, but never her past life. We knew she had a male friend, was and had always been unmarried, and had been friends with our chief editor for many years. That's all we knew. 

Fast forward to the next century, and the whole world is Googling people they used to know. And there she is... with her own Wikipedia page...Natalie Marcin. Writer of the original Anchors Aweigh. She had been invited to California to watch as they filmed her story, but her parents felt she was too young. And yes, she had been rich. And she certainly knew which was better!

How I wish I had asked her more about herself when I had the chance!

@Barry Ancona

I think the problem is that fees are not taxes.  Think of all the added charges that Ticketmaster adds to their prices. Those are fees. They’re not taxes. 

On the other hands, my Verizon bill has a number of nuisance taxes added. But those are mandated by the government. Those are taxes but not fees.

Both are legit, but a tax is not a fee. So much so that without realizing it, my first guess was “nuisance fee,” forgetting “fee” was in the clue.

Alas, probably close enough for government work (or non-government work).  And crossword puzzles.

@RozzieGrandma

Here's Google's AI's take on it: 

Both Horace Greeley and Eugene Meyer are associated with the question "Are there any news?". It is likely that this anecdote was passed down and attributed to multiple figures over time. 

Horace Greeley
The anecdote: The story goes that Horace Greeley, the influential editor of the New-York Tribune, impatiently cabled one of his correspondents, "Are there any news?". The correspondent, with a firm grip on the grammar of the time, humorously cabled back: "Sorry, not a single new". This version emphasizes Greeley's impatience and the correspondent's witty reply.

Context: Greeley's influence on journalism was immense, and such stories about his eccentricities and high standards would have become part of journalistic lore.
